replies.body: Welp, there goes my porn stash, I mean, uh....yea....
Same.

Meh, just put a bag over her head, that or don't take the mask off.
According to the internet she still has a nice boo-Tay.

http://177etz3mauip3sw0he3ac6hppjz.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/will-smith-620x400.jpg
Annie has an Adali.

I think you meant {{champion:84}} doll... You typed Adali...

EDIT (one day later): At the time of this comment I seriously thought it was a typo. Not a joke. Though now I get it.
Did you say it out loud?

I did... I just don't think I would prounounce it the same... Ad - ali

Thats kinda how I pronounced it.

a -colly
a-dolly
I get it now... It just didn't work for me at first due to how I pronounced it when I read it.
I was thinking of saying "Adolli" but it looked like shit.

Nah, Akali is pronounced more like Dahl than Doll. It's an absurdly minor difference that would almost certainly escape the notice of a non-native speaker (and might also be dependent on dialect and/or accent) but I agree with you that Akali doesn't quite rhyme with A Dolly.
how the fuck do you pronounce doll? dahl is the pronunciation guide for doll.

It's mostly an intonation difference. Akali has a rising intonation on the "ka" while Doll is flat the whole way.

As I said, nitpicky native-speaker stuff that probably varies even within America let alone the other countries with different dialects of English. I certainly would understand what you meant if you said "Doll" with a rising intonation since English doesn't technically (as far as I know) officially designate intonation for words, but if you ask me whether "Akali" and "A dolly" rhyme perfectly I would say no.

I really want to skype or curse with you so i can understand your accent. I am honestly so confused. i understand accents, i have one myself, but I have never heard one that has the ali part of akali sound different than dolly.

I mean, the stress is the same, uhkahlee, uh dahlee, heck in pseudo phonetic typing they are spelled nearly the same. 

and yes, before you ask, I have been saying akali, a dolly to myself a dozen or so times while writing this, I even made a little rhyme of sorts.

Calling Akali A Dolly is Prolly A Folly. 

yes I know prolly isn't a word, but it fits. it is slang for probably, incase you were unaware.

I lived in Minnesota for 18 years, while my family comes from New England. Don't know what that does to my accent, but those should be the biggest influences.

Try saying the "ka" in Akali like "car" with a really bad fake Boston accent. Maybe try to make it a bit nasally. Doll on the other hand is much closer to Dull. I'm exaggerating to emphasize the differences, but those are the directions I would characterize their differences.

Of course, it's entirely possible that I'm objectively wrong and they 100% should be identical. For all I know I'm even imagining the differences when I'm saying it myself.

(If you're interested, I also think Folly rhymes with Akali, while Prolly rhymes with Dolly.)
It's a decent slant rhyme though

I pronounce it A K A(accented) L I. Like, with full open As, not half-Es or half-Os.
So A D A L I doesn't mean much to me.
